answer_html: \(\displaystyle y=b^7\) which is simply a horizontal line at the height b7 and so its tangent line is itself, that is, the line y = b7.
answer_latex:
$\displaystyle
y=b^7$  which is simply a horizontal line at the height
\emph{b}\textsuperscript{7} and so its tangent line is itself, that is,
the line \emph{y} = \emph{b}\textsuperscript{7}.
hints_html: If a = 0, just plug that in to see what the problem becomes.
hints_latex: If \emph{a} = 0, just plug that in to see what the problem becomes.
hints_raw: If ''a'' = 0, just plug that in to see what the problem becomes.
question: 8 (b)
sols_html:
If a = 0, then the curve we are looking at is the curve

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = (0x+b)^7 = b^7\end{aligned}\]

which is simply a horizontal line at the height b7 and so its tangent line is itself, that is, the line y = b7.
sols_latex:
If \emph{a} = 0, then the curve we are looking at is the curve

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
y = (0x+b)^7 = b^7
\end{align*} which is simply a horizontal line at the height
\emph{b}\textsuperscript{7} and so its tangent line is itself, that is,
the line \emph{y} = \emph{b}\textsuperscript{7}.
sols_raw:
If ''a'' = 0, then the curve we are looking at is the curve
:<math>\displaystyle
y = (0x+b)^7 = b^7
</math>
which is simply a horizontal line at the height ''b''<sup>7</sup> and so its tangent line is itself, that is, the line ''y'' = ''b''<sup>7</sup>.
statement_html:
Let \(y = (ax + b)^7\), where a and b are constant.

(b) Now suppose that \(a = 0\). Find the equation of the tangent line in this case.
statement_latex:
Let $y = (ax + b)^7$, where \emph{a} and \emph{b} are constant.

(b) Now suppose that $a = 0$. Find the equation of the tangent line in
this case.
statement_raw:
Let <math>y = (ax + b)^7 </math>, where ''a'' and ''b'' are constant. 

(b) Now suppose that <math> a = 0</math>.  Find the equation of the tangent line in this case.
